Name: Introduction to Biomolecular Engineering
Description: Introduces bio-related careers in chemical engineering, providing foundational knowledge in molecular cell biology and biochemistry for early undergraduate students. Highlights the connections between biology and chemical engineering, helping students understand interdisciplinary concepts that are essential for biomolecular engineering
Prerequisites:
Prereq: (Sophomore Standing or Chemical Engineering Major) and (CHM 2045 or
CHM 2095 or CHM 2050). 
Coreq:  CHM 2046 or CHM 2096 or CHM 2051.

Name: Computer Model Formulation
Description: Solutions of scientific and engineering problems using digital computers. Formulation of models for describing physical processes, numerical analysis, and computer programming.
Prerequisites: Prereq: COP 2273 with a grade of C or better and MAP 2302 and MAC 2313.

Name: Professional Development of Chemical Engineers
Description: Introduces the Chemical Engineering profession and a wide range of careers, including chemical, energy, pharmaceutical, semiconductor, and food industries, as well as graduate and professional school pathways. Provides resources to build successful professional careers, including best practices for interviewing, oral presentations, and teamwork. Also discusses professional codes of conduct and ethical decision-making.

Name: Material and Energy Balances
Description: Formulation and solution of material and energy balances utilizing physical/chemical properties of matter as applied to analyzing unit operations systems.
Prerequisites: Prereq: (CHM 2045 or CHM 2095 or CHM 2050) & MAC 2312 & PHY 2048; Coreq: (CHM 2046 or CHM 2096 or CHM 2051) & MAC 2313 & MAP 2302 & ECH 2934

Name: Process Thermodynamics
Description: Introduces fundamental principles of classical and statistical thermodynamics. Application of the first and second laws of thermodynamics to the modeling and analysis of physical and chemical processes undergoing change, such as liquefaction, refrigeration, and power generation.
Prerequisites: Prereq: COP 2273 and ECH 3023. Coreq: COT 3502.

Name: Fluid and Solid Operations
Description: Characteristics of laminar and turbulent flow, mechanical energy balance, flow through packed beds and fluidization of solids, design of pumping systems and piping networks and metering of fluids.

Name: Energy Transfer Operations
Description: Steady state conduction in solids and heterogeneous materials, transient conduction, convection heat transfer, heat transfer during boiling and condensation, radiation heat transfer, design of heat-transfer equipment and heat exchange networks.

Name: Elementary Transport Phenomena
Description: Flux law and conservation equations of mass, energy, and momentum; solution of transport problems associated with physical and chemical processing; macroscopic and microscopic analysis.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ECH 3023 and MAP 2302 and MAC 2313.

Name: Phase and Chemical Equilibria
Description: Application of thermodynamic principles to systems of variable composition, including the study of phase and chemical equilibria.

Name: Fluid and Energy Transfer Operations Laboratory
Description: Laboratory work in unit operations involving heat and momentum transfer.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ECH 3101 and ECH 3203 and ECH 3223 and STA 3032 or STA 2023; Coreq: ECH 4714 and ENC 2256.

Name: Process Control Theory
Description: Analysis and automatic control of process systems in chemical engineering.

Name: Process Control Laboratory
Description: Laboratory work associated with ECH 4323.

Name: Separation and Mass Transfer Operations
Description: Theory, design, and evaluation of diffusional and staged mass transfer processes including distillation, absorption and extraction, leaching, and membrane separations. Computer-aided design methods.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ECH 3101 and ECH 3203 and ECH 3223.

Name: Separation and Mass Transfer Operations Laboratory
Description: Laboratory work in unit operations involving mass transfer. (WR)
Prerequisites: Prereq: ECH 4403 and ECH 4224L and ECH 4714.

Name: Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
Description: Homogeneous and heterogeneous reaction kinetic modeling and data analysis. Analysis and design of ideal batch, mixed, plug and recycle reactors. Heterogeneous catalysis and reactor design.

Name: Process Economics and Optimization
Description: Introduces the principles of process economics including specifications and costing of equipment, operations costing and economic evaluation of processes.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ECH 3203 and ECH 3223; Coreq: ECH 4403.

Name: Process Design
Description: Preliminary design of convention chemical processes including process specifications, sitting and layout, equipment sizing, utility and manpower needs, safety and hazard analysis, environmental considerations and economic evaluation. Planning techniques for detailed engineering, construction and startup.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ECH 4403 and ECH 4504 and ECH 4604 and ECH 4824.

Name: Chemical Process Safety
Description: Laboratory and process safety analysis which emphasizes prevention and mitigation. Application of chemical engineering principles to assessing hazards and risk.

Name: Pharmaceutical Bioengineering
Description:
Introduces concepts, challenges, and technologies in the modern
pharmaceutical industry and laboratory, focused on biologics (drugs derived from living organisms).
Prerequisites: Prereq: (BME 2402 or BSC 2010) & (CHM 2046 or CHM 2096 or CHM 2051).

Name: Materials of Chemical Engineering
Description: Relations between microscopic structure and macroscopic mechanical, thermal and electrical properties of organic and inorganic solids. Engineering applications, including corrosion.

Name: Special Problems in Chemical Engineering: Management of Unit Ops
Description: Study of chemical engineering problems as identified by the student and instructor.

Name: Special Problems in Chemical Engineering: Transport in Soft Materials
Description: Study of chemical engineering problems as identified by the student and instructor.

Name: Special Problems in Chemical Engineering: Sustainable Engineering
Description: Study of chemical engineering problems as identified by the student and instructor.

Name: Special Problems in Chemical Engineering: Chemical Process Data Science
Description: Study of chemical engineering problems as identified by the student and instructor.

Name: Special Problems in Chemical Engineering: Impedance Spectroscopy
Description: Study of chemical engineering problems as identified by the student and instructor.

Name: Internship Work Experience
Description: Practical internship work experience under approved industrial supervision, as set forth in college regulations. A maximum of 3 credits from ECH 4948 and ECH 4949 can count towards the Chemical Engineering degree. For example, a student who has earned 1 credit of ECH 4949, can only have 2 credits of ECH 4948 count towards the degree.

Name: Co-op Work Experience
Description: Practical co-op work experience under approved industrial supervision, as set forth in college regulations. A maximum of 3 credits from ECH 4949 and ECH 4948 can count towards the Chemical Engineering degree. For example, a student who has earned 1 credit of ECH 4948, can only have 2 credits of ECH 4949 count towards the degree.

Name: Molecular Thermodynamics of Chemical Engineering
Description: Statistical mechanics and microscopic explanation of macroscopic laws of classical thermodynamics, transport phenomena, and chemical kinetics. Statistical mechanical theories that connect molecular structure to macroscopic properties.

Name: Transport Phenomena
Description: Integrated introduction to transport processes in continuous media with emphasis on fluid mechanics and heat and mass transfer.
Prerequisites: Prereq: Admission to the ChE graduate program or by consent of instructor, dependent upon prior background in undergraduate fluid mechanics and heat and mass transfer, at a level required to obtain an undergraduate degree in Chemical Engineering.

Name: Chemical Process Data Science
Description: Applications of fundamental data science visualization methods and algorithms, with a strong emphasis on examples from integrated chemical processes and computational materials design and discovery.

Name: Advanced Mathematics for Chemical Engineering
Description: Methods of linear systems, chemical engineering applications in finite and infinite dimensional spaces, concepts of stability, application to transport phenomena.

Name: Impedance Spectroscopy
Description: Intended for chemists, physicists, materials scientists, and engineers with an interest in applying electrochemical impedance techniques to study a broad variety of electrochemical processes.
Prerequisites: Prereq: familiarity with applications of differential equations.

Name: Individual Work: Management of Unit Ops
Description: Independent study to gain knowledge of a topic not offered in other coursework that is guided by an instructor. Not intended for students actively participating in efforts contributing to work of a specific research group.

Name: Individual Work
Description: Independent study to gain knowledge of a topic not offered in other coursework that is guided by an instructor. Not intended for students actively participating in efforts contributing to work of a specific research group.

Name: Graduate Seminar
Description: Graduate Seminar

Name: Topics in Chemical Engineering I: Sustainable Engineering
Description: Covers advanced and contemporary topics in chemical engineering.

Name: Topics in Chemical Engineering I: Advanced Chem Bio Lab
Description: Covers advanced and contemporary topics in chemical engineering.

Name: Topics in Chemical Engineering I: Pharmaceutical Bioengineering
Description: Covers advanced and contemporary topics in chemical engineering.

Name: Topics in Chemical Engineering I: Transport in Soft Materials
Description: Covers advanced and contemporary topics in chemical engineering.

Name: Natural Language Processing
Description: Covers concepts in natural language processing ranging from shallow bag-of words to richer representations and formalisms, for applications such as translation, generation, extraction, summarization, and dialogue. Classic and state-of-the-art techniques and remaining challenges are discussed, as well as recent proposals for meeting those challenges (both symbolic and machine learning approaches). Intended for graduate students doing research related to natural language processing.
Prerequisites:
Prereq: Proficiency in programming (Python recommended) & familiarity with
introductory machine learning or artificial intelligence is a plus.

Name: Introduction to Computational Media
Description: Examines the tools, technologies, and programming techniques used to make visually-oriented applications. Topics include the foundational elements of both 2D and 3D graphics, content creation tools, and the intersection of art and computing.

Name: Introduction to Computer-Aided Modeling
Description: Introduces topics related to computer-aided modeling. Polygonal mesh, NURBS and subdivision surface meshes. Materials and shading networks. Lighting, shadows and rendering.

Name: Computer Vision
Description: Introduction to computer vision and is intended for senior level undergraduate students who want to delve into this exciting and challenging sub-field of AI. Learn the basics of computer vision starting with how camera images are formed and how algorithms can take images in digital form and manipulate them to infer the content of the image, track objects in videos for surveillance applications, or perform morphometric analysis.
Prerequisites: Prereq: (COT 4501 or MAD 4401 B) and COT 3100, all with minimum grades of B.

Name: Natural Language Processing
Description: Introduction to the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of Natural Language Processing (NLP). Practical application and theoretical concepts are examined. Topics include information extraction, language construction, grammars, disambiguation, as well as system modeling, classification, and evaluation.

Name: Computer Vision
Description: Introduction to image formation and analysis. Monocular imaging system projections, camera model calibration, and binocular imaging. Low-level vision techniques, segmentation and representation techniques, and high-level vision.
Prerequisites: Prereq: PrerequisitesMAC 2312 or equivalent, COT 4501 or equivalent and Proficiency in MATLAB or C++ or Java. Course instructor will determine equivalency.

Name: Bioinformatics
Description: Basic concepts of molecular biology and computer science. Sequence comparison and assembly, physical mapping of DNA, phylogenetic trees, genome rearrangements, gene identification, biomolecular cryptology, and molecular structure prediction.

Name: Computer Graphics
Description: Display device characteristics; system considerations, display algorithms. Curve and surface generation. Lighting models and image rendering.

Name: Introduction to Data Science
Description: Introducing the basics of data science including programming for data analytics, file management, relational databases, classification, clustering and regression. The foundation is laid for big data applications ranging from social networks to medical and business informatics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: COP 3530 Data Structures and Algorithms or equivalent.

Name: Advanced Machine Learning
Description: Advanced concepts in developing computer programs that learn and improve with experience. Emphasis on methods based on probability, statistics, and optimization.

Name: Introduction to Computer Organization
Description: Organization of computing systems. Logical basis of computer structure. Machine representation of instructions and data, flow of control, and basic machine instructions. Assembly language programming.
Prerequisites: Prereq: (COP 3504 or COP 3503) and (MAC 2233 or MAC 2311 or MAC 3472) and COT 3100.

Name: Computer Architecture
Description: Introduces computer architecture and system organization including virtual memory supports cache, pipeline, vector processing, multiprocessor and RISC architecture.

Name: Cyber-physical System Security
Description: Covers foundational concepts of cyber-physical system security. In particular, hardware and software threats and mitigation strategies of integrating sensing and actuation, AI computation, infrastructure control, and networking. Students will analyze research papers, write technical essays, present security research problems, conduct hands-on testing, and learn the challenges of building secure systems.

Name: Computer Architecture Principles
Description: Fundamental design issues of processor and computer architecture, a variety of design approaches for CPU, memory, and system structure.

Name: Cyber-physical System Security
Description:
Covers foundational concepts of cyber-physical system security. In particular, hardware and software threats and mitigation strategies of integrating sensing and actuation, AI computation, infrastructure control, and networking. Students will analyze research papers, write technical essays, present security research problems, conduct hands-on testing, and learn the
challenges of building secure systems.
Prerequisites: Prereq: Basic proficiency with programming is required (e.g., Python, C++).

Name: Introduction to Software Engineering
Description: Topics include software planning, specifications, coding, testing and maintenance. Gain experience in the team approach to large system development.

Name: Human-Computer Interaction
Description: Studies the major topics in the study, planning and design of the interaction between people and computers. Topics include interface design (principles, theories and guidelines), virtual environments, interactive devices and collaboration.

Name: User Experience Design
Description: Introduces methods and tools used in User Experience Design (UXD): the early stages of software design focused on meeting user needs. Key concepts include user research, contextual design, design thinking, ideation, iterative design, prototyping, and design documentation. Projects utilize software tools used in the industry.

Name: User Experience Design
Description: Introduces methods and tools used in User Experience Design (UXD): the early stages of software design focused on meeting user needs. Key concepts include user research, contextual design, design thinking, ideation, iterative design, prototyping, and design documentation. Software tools used in industry are used in class projects.

Name: Introduction to Bioinformatic Algorithms
Description: Uses Compeau and Pevzner’s active learning approach from their textbook, Bioinformatics Algorithms, to cover fundamental topics in genomics, machine learning, and biological data science, striking a unique balance between practical challenges in modern biology and fundamental algorithmic ideas.
Prerequisites:
Prereq: COT 3100 with minimum grade of C and COP 3503C with minimum grade
of C or COP 3504C with minimum grade of C.

Name: Information and Database Systems 1
Description: First part of a two-course sequence that studies the essential concepts, principles and techniques of modern database systems. Topics include modeling and querying of data using conceptual data models as well as the development of a database application.

Name: CS Teaching & Learning
Description: Covers basic pedagogy, especially as it relates to computer science and engineering, and covers three fundamental elements in education: learning environment, educational theory, and educational practice as approached to engineering-specific training.

Name: Individual Study in CISE
Description: Problems in different areas of computer science.
Prerequisites: Prereq: COP 3502C with a minimum grade of C.

Name: Senior Project
Description: Involves completing a significant CISE-related project. Coordinate with the instructor and a project advisor, prepare a detailed technical report and deliver an oral presentation.
Prerequisites: Prereq: senior CISE standing or higher and approved project proposal.

Name: Special Topics in CISE: Enterprise Software Eng.
Description: Variable content provides an opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered elsewhere and of topics of current significance.
Prerequisites: Prereq: COP 3503C or COP 3504C or instructor permission.

Name: Trustworthy Machine Learning
Description: Explores research at the intersection of machine learning and security and privacy. Topics include: adversarial machine learning; differential privacy; membership inference; fairness & transparency; explainable/interpretable machine learning; deepfakes and disinformation.
Prerequisites: Prereq: Knowledge of programming fundamentals, familiarity with machine learning and Python is a plus.

Name: Computer Network Fundamentals
Description: Fundamental concepts, principles, and standards of computer networks. Introduces topics in top-down approach, starting with the application layer in the OSI system architecture with a stronger focus on application, transport, and network layers.

Name: Multimedia Networking Principles
Description: Design and analysis of multimedia networking. Major effort is devoted on multimedia elements, and their impact on higher-level protocols at the application- and transport-layer.
Prerequisites: Prereq: CNT 4007 with minimum grade of C.

Name: Computer Networks
Description: Design, implementation, and internals of networks. Routing, congestion control, internetworking, TCP/IP, optimization, and proxy services.

Name: Programming Fundamentals 1
Description: First course of a two-semester introductory sequence for those planning further study in computer science, digital arts and sciences or computer engineering. Concepts of computer science and the process of computer programming, including object-oriented programming, procedural and data abstraction and program modularity.

Name: Advanced Programming Fundamentals for CIS Majors

Name: Data Structures and Algorithm
Description: Algorithm development using pseudo languages, basic program structures, program design techniques, storage and manipulation of basic data structures like arrays, stacks, queues, sorting and searching and string processing. Linked linear lists. Trees and multilinked structures.
Prerequisites: Prereq: (COP 3504 or COP 3503) and COT 3100 and (MAC 2234 or MAC 2312 or MAC 2512 or MAC 3473), all with a minimum grade of C.
Meet Times: [{'meetNo': 1, 'meetDays': ['T'], 'meetTimeBegin': '1:55 PM', 'meetTimeEnd': '2:45 PM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '7', 'meetPeriodEnd': '7', 'meetBuilding': 'CAR', 'meetBldgCode': '0022', 'meetRoom': '0100'}, {'meetNo': 2, 'meetDays': ['R'], 'meetTimeBegin': '1:55 PM', 'meetTimeEnd': '3:50 PM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '7', 'meetPeriodEnd': '8', 'meetBuilding': 'CAR', 'meetBldgCode': '0022', 'meetRoom': '0100'}, {'meetNo': 3, 'meetDays': ['W'], 'meetTimeBegin': '10:40 AM', 'meetTimeEnd': '11:30 AM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '4', 'meetPeriodEnd': '4', 'meetBuilding': 'NRN', 'meetBldgCode': '0101', 'meetRoom': '1037'}]

Name: Programming Language Concepts
Description: Introduces programming language principles, including language constructs, design goals, run-time structures, implementation techniques and exposure to a wide variety of programming paradigms.

Name: Algorithm Abstraction and Design
Description: Covers algorithmic concepts and their use rooted in practical application and computer science theory. Topics include algorithmic paradigms, limits of computing, and algorithm time complexity classes.

Name: Operating Systems
Description: Design and implementation of various components of a modern operating system, including I/O programming, interrupt handling, process and resource management, computer networks and distributed systems.
Prerequisites: Prereq: CDA 3101 and COP 3530; knowledge of C or C++ recommended.
Meet Times: [{'meetNo': 1, 'meetDays': ['T'], 'meetTimeBegin': '3:00 PM', 'meetTimeEnd': '4:55 PM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '8', 'meetPeriodEnd': '9', 'meetBuilding': 'CAR', 'meetBldgCode': '0022', 'meetRoom': '0100'}, {'meetNo': 2, 'meetDays': ['R'], 'meetTimeBegin': '4:05 PM', 'meetTimeEnd': '4:55 PM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '9', 'meetPeriodEnd': '9', 'meetBuilding': 'CAR', 'meetBldgCode': '0022', 'meetRoom': '0100'}, {'meetNo': 3, 'meetDays': ['W'], 'meetTimeBegin': '5:10 PM', 'meetTimeEnd': '6:00 PM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '10', 'meetPeriodEnd': '10', 'meetBuilding': 'CSE', 'meetBldgCode': '0042', 'meetRoom': 'E221'}]

Name: Advanced Data Structures
Description: Development of efficient data structures used to obtain more efficient solutions to classical problems, such as those based on graph theoretical models, as well as problems that arise in application areas of contemporary interest.

Name: Distributed Operating System Principles
Description: Concepts and techniques for efficient management of computer system resources.

Name: Applications of Discrete Structures
Description: Covers the mathematics of discrete events; i.e., events that involve distinct elements, finite structures of distinct elements or finite sampled versions of continuous phenomena (such as movement).
Prerequisites: Prereq: (MAC 2311 or MAC 3472) and (COP 3502C or equivalent), all with a minimum grades of C; Coreq: COP 3504 or COP 3503.
Meet Times: [{'meetNo': 1, 'meetDays': ['M'], 'meetTimeBegin': '3:00 PM', 'meetTimeEnd': '3:50 PM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '8', 'meetPeriodEnd': '8', 'meetBuilding': 'FAB', 'meetBldgCode': '0598', 'meetRoom': '0103'}, {'meetNo': 2, 'meetDays': ['T'], 'meetTimeBegin': '8:30 AM', 'meetTimeEnd': '10:25 AM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '2', 'meetPeriodEnd': '3', 'meetBuilding': 'CAR', 'meetBldgCode': '0022', 'meetRoom': '0100'}, {'meetNo': 3, 'meetDays': ['R'], 'meetTimeBegin': '9:35 AM', 'meetTimeEnd': '10:25 AM', 'meetPeriodBegin': '3', 'meetPeriodEnd': '3', 'meetBuilding': 'CAR', 'meetBldgCode': '0022', 'meetRoom': '0100'}]

Name: Analysis of Algorithms
Description: Introduction and illustration of basic techniques for designing efficient algorithms and analyzing algorithm complexity.

Name: Mathematics for Intelligent Systems
Description: Mathematical methods commonly used to develop algorithms for computer systems that exhibit intelligent behavior.
Prerequisites: Prereq: MAC 2313, Multivariate Calculus; MAS 3114 or MAS 4105, Linear Algebra; STA 4321, Mathematical Statistics.

Name: Engineering Directed Independent Research
Description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

Name: Engineering Directed Independent Research: Computer Engineering Research
Description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

Name: Practicum/Internship/Cooperative Work Experience
Description: Practical cooperative engineering work under approved industrial and faculty supervision.

Name: Africa Since 1800
Description: End of the slave trade and the growth of legitimate commerce; Islamic renewal and revolution; the European partition and the colonial era; the growth of nationalism and the reemergence of independent Africa.
Prerequisites: Prereq:  ​3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: Special Topics in African History: Health & Healing in African Hy
Description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Africa.
Prerequisites: Credits: 3; can be repeated with change in content up to 18 credits; Prereq: 3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: United States to 1877
Description: In this course, students will examine United States history from before European contact to 1877. Topics will include but are not limited to indigenous peoples, the European background, the colonial period, the American Revolution, the Articles of Confederation, the Constitution, issues within the new Republic, sectionalism, manifest destiny, slavery, the American Civil War, and Reconstruction.

Name: United States Since 1877
Description: In this course, students will trace the history of the United States from the end of the Reconstruction era to the contemporary era. Topics will include but are not limited to the rise of Industrialization, the United States’ emergence as an actor on the world stage, Constitutional amendments and their impact, the Progressive era, World War I, the Great Depression and New Deal, World War II, the Civil Rights era, the Cold War, and the United States since 1989.

Name: Florida to 1845
Description: Exploration, settlement, and colonial history of Spanish and British Florida from US territorial days to statehood.

Name: US Urban History
Description: Analyzes the growth and development of urban civilization in the US, emphasizing how cities began and their impact on politics, economics, and culture.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of history with a minimum grade of C.

Name: Diversity in American History
Description: Examines the diversity of the American people and its changes over time from first European contact to the present. Focuses on the interaction between different ethnic groups in American history and how the changing notions of race have helped shape the contours of that history.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits in AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, HIS, LAH, or WOH.

Name: American Environmental History
Description: Substantive and interpretative inquiry of the historical roots of the nation's contemporary environmental issues. A comprehensive overview of the relationship between people and their natural physical surroundings from the Columbian explorations to the 1980s.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ​6 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: Special Topics in American History: AfricanAmerican HY 1865 - Pres
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: Special Topics in American History: Slavery and Black Girlhood
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: Special Topics in American History: Culture Wars
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: Special Topics in American History: LatinX MigrationRefugees in US
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: Special Topics in American History: Seminar in Public History
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: Special Topics in American History: Health Equity and Community
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: Special Topics in American History: History of Delinquency
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

Name: US Since World War II
Description: Post-World War II America: America as world power, social revolution, Vietnam, Watergate, and after.

Name: Violence and Social Conflict in American History
Description: Changing patterns and levels of violent behavior during the last four centuries of American history, including rioting, lynching, domestic violence, and street violence.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ​6 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: American Civil War and Reconstruction
Description: Analyzes the political, social, and economic transformation of the Union, highlighting the presidency of Lincoln, the evolution of federal policies of Unionist loyalty and slave emancipation, the development of Union military leadership, and the tragically unsuccessful post-war attempt to provide justice to the freed people.

Name: History Research Seminar: US: American Disasters
Description: Introduces the historiography of a specific topic and production of a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.
Prerequisites: Prereq: HIS 3942 with a minimum grade of C.

Name: History Research Seminar: US: What are Universities For
Description: Introduces the historiography of a specific topic and production of a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.
Prerequisites: Prereq: HIS 3942 with a minimum grade of C.

Name: Modern Japan
Description: Surveys the social, political and economic transformation of modern Japanese society from 1800.

Name: Special Topics in Asian History: Ottoman Palestine 1516-1918
Description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

Name: Special Topics in Asian History: Jews in the Muslim World
Description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

Name: Special Topics in Asian History: Modern Middle East
Description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

Name: Special Topics in Asian History: Human Rights in Asia
Description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

Name: Special Topics in Asian History: Arabian Nights
Description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

Name: Medieval Eastern Europe
Description: Eastern Europe from late Antiquity to the 15th century. Examines the major problems of medieval history, with special emphasis on the role of the region in the history of the continent.
Prerequisites: Prereq:  ​3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: Colonies to Commonwealth: the History of the British Empire
Description: History of the British Empire from its origins in Ireland to the decolonization movements of the 20th century. Examines not only the ways in which the British established and extended the empire through the political, military, economic, and cultural spheres, but also resistance to empire.
Prerequisites: Prereq:  ​3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: Special Topics in European History: Marx and Money
Description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Europe.

Name: Special Topics in European History: The Scientific Revolution
Description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Europe.

Name: Special Topics in European History: Eng. in European Middle Ages
Description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Europe.

Name: Nineteenth-Century Germany
Description: Germany's political development toward nationhood in the 19th century, and the imperial policies of Bismarck and Wilhelm II. The social history of specific groups in German society. Germany's role in the outbreak of WW I. Offered alternate years.

Name: History Research Seminar: Europe: World War II in Europe
Description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.
Prerequisites: Prereq: HIS 3942 with a minimum grade of C.

Name: Topics in European History: Material Culture and History
Description: Topics in European History

Name: The Scientific Revolution
Description: Emergence of modern science from Copernicus to Newton exploring the notions of empiricism, experiment, mechanism, materialism, and the historical concepts of continuity, change, revolution, and progress.

Name: History Practicum: Slavery in British Atlantic
Description: Learn the elements of the professional study of history: the critical reading of sources (primary and secondary); research skills; and a variety of historical methodologies.

Name: History Practicum: The Long Civil Rights
Description: Learn the elements of the professional study of history: the critical reading of sources (primary and secondary); research skills; and a variety of historical methodologies.

Name: History Practicum: The Conquest of Mexico
Description: Learn the elements of the professional study of history: the critical reading of sources (primary and secondary); research skills; and a variety of historical methodologies.

Name: History Practicum: Women in Early America
Description: Learn the elements of the professional study of history: the critical reading of sources (primary and secondary); research skills; and a variety of historical methodologies.

Name: History Honors Workshop
Description: Assists with all phases of the senior thesis, including project design, research, writing, and oral presentation. Students complete assignments that build toward a draft of a preliminary chapter or the introduction. The workshop provides a collaborative environment in which to pursue individual thesis projects.
Prerequisites: Prereq: acceptance into the History Honors program.

Name: Introduction to Historiography
Description: Introduction to the schools, theories, and philosophies of the discipline of history.

Name: Colonial Latin America
Description: Surveys the formation of Spanish and Portuguese imperial systems and colonial societies in America in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.

Name: Contemporary Latin America
Description: Contemporary challenges to traditional structures; revolution and evolution.
Prerequisites: Prereq:  ​3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: Race, Religion, and Revolution in the Black Caribbean
Description: Explores the history of Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic and the Miskito Coast of Nicaragua. Explains the emergence of colonial and neo-colonial political systems, the concept of race in relationship to slavery and global capitalism as well as the role of religion in revolutionary actions.

Name: Special Topics in Latin American History: Social Movements and Gender
Description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

Name: History Research Seminar: Latin America: Latin America's Cold War
Description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.
Prerequisites: Prereq: HIS 3942 with a minimum grade of C.

Name: Topics in Latin American History: Comparative Slavery
Description: Topics in Latin American History

Name: Pirates and Piracy: A Global History
Description: An examination of the history of pirates and piracy from antiquity through to the present day. Major themes include: the changing definitions of piracy; the reasons individuals, groups, and nations have practiced or supported piracy; and how pirates have been depicted in popular culture.

Name: History of Christianity 1
Description: Surveys the history of Christianity, c. 100 to c. 1300, from its status as a persecuted minority religion of the Roman Empire to its position of dominance in the civilizations of medieval Europe and Byzantium.
Prerequisites: Prereq:  ​3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

Name: Special Topics in World History: Empires in History & Myth
Description: Selected variable topics in world history.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits in AFH, ASH, AMH, EUH, HIS, LAH or WOH.

Name: Special Topics in World History: The Cold War in Global Context
Description: Selected variable topics in world history.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits in AFH, ASH, AMH, EUH, HIS, LAH or WOH.

Name: History Research Seminar: World History: Archives Fragments Writing HY
Description: Introduces the historiography of a specific topic; requires a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.
Prerequisites: Prereq: HIS 3942 with a minimum grade of C.

Name: Topics in World History: Cities of the Modern World
Description: Examines major themes and topics in world history.

Name: Survey of American Literature
Description: This class will survey American literature and narrative from the precolonial period through to the present, largely structured chronologically. Throughout our class, we will read famous, well-known texts that are considered part of the Western canon and lesser-known texts or texts that are not often featured in general-education literature syllabi. The canon refers to the body of literature that is considered high-quality, artistic, and valued representations of American identity.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

Name: Issues in American Literature and Culture
Description: Introduces some of the most important issues that arise in the study of American literature and culture. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of the topic. (WR)
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

Name: Variable Surveys of American Literatures: Queer Latinidades
Description: The rich cultural traditions found in American literature. Topics may include gay and lesbian, Jewish American, Chicano/a, Latino/a, Native American, Southern, and other literatures. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: African American Literature 2
Description: Surveys the development of African American Literature from 1945 to the present.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Studies in American Literary Forms: American Gothic
Description: Study of genre, such as the novel, detective novel, political novel, historical novel, utopian fiction, or Western; drama; short story; sermon traditions; African American cultural forms, African American folklore; long poem, lyric, philosophical poem, oral poetry; nature writing, autobiography, captivity narrative; narratives of exploration; political oratory; postmodernism; coming-out stories; humor. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Studies in American Literature and Culture Before 1800: Early American Lit to 1830
Description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms, or themes in the study of American literature and culture before 1800. Topics may include narratives of exploration and encounter, Puritan and/or Enlightenment writings, captivity and slave narratives, traditions of spiritual autobiography, post-colonial approaches to colonial rhetoric and poetry, and/or in-depth studies of selected writers. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Studies of Genders and Sexualities in American Literature and Culture: Queer Lit bef "Honosexuality"
Description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms, or themes in the study of American literature and culture. Topics may include masculinity and femininity in literature, lesbian possibilities in popular culture, feminism and womanism, traditions of gay self-representation. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Major Figures of American Literature and Culture: Ursula K. LeGuin
Description: In-depth focus on one major author, such as Dickinson, Twain, Faulkner, Hurston, or Morrison. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Major Figures of American Literature and Culture: Octavia Butler
Description: In-depth focus on one major author, such as Dickinson, Twain, Faulkner, Hurston, or Morrison. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Studies in American Literature and Culture: Post-Civil Rights Lit and Law
Description: Variable topics examine issues, movements, forms, or themes that cross traditional period boundaries. Topics may include the city and the country in American fiction, Southern masculinity, reading and literacy in America, representations of class and religion in American literature, the body and technology, American regionalisms, the Pragmatist tradition, and nature and eco-criticism in American letters. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Beginning Fiction Writing
Description: For students who want to write fiction. Includes basics and heavy reading. Students write stories and their fiction is discussed in workshop.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

Name: Beginning Poetry Writing
Description: Concentrates on basics of reading and writing poetry. Some student writing will be discussed in workshop.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

Name: Fiction Writing
Description: Instruction in basic techniques of voice, plot and character while introducing advanced ones.

Name: Advanced Seminar in Fiction Writing
Description: Small workshop for students who have made their way out of beginner's workshops with sanity intact. Now the work gets more difficult, more deranged and more delightful. Emerson said, "People do not deserve to have good writing, they are so pleased with bad." Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

Name: Advanced Seminar in Poetry Writing
Description: "More reeling and writhing," as Lewis Carroll said. An intense workshop for a small group of poets who have stared at the Pacific with a wild surmise. Like Balboa - or was it Cortez? Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

Name: Creative Nonfiction
Description: Creative writing workshop which introduces genres of creative nonfiction (e.g. memoir, personal essay, travel writing) and provides training in those genres. Appropriate for, but not limited to, English majors.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 6 credits of AML, CRW, ENG, ENL, or LIT.

Name: Senior Advanced Workshop in Fiction Writing: SEN ADV FICTION WORK
Description: For students who want to trouble the literary editors and readers of the future. Many members of this class have gone on to graduate school in writing. Ants eat everything that is written, said an explorer. This is a workshop for ants. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

Name: Fiction Writing
Description: Fiction Writing

Name: Studies in Literary Form: Apollonian & Dionysian
Description: Formal aspects of literature.

Name: Verse Writing
Description: Verse Writing

Name: Multimodal Writing and Digital Literacy
Description: Teaches digital literacy and digital creativity. Compose and convey creative, well-researched, carefully crafted information through digital platforms and multimodal documents. Also promotes digital writing and research as central to academic, civic, and personal expression.

Name: Topics for Composition
Description: Instruction in expository-argumentative writing related to one special topic selected by the instructor. Readings include variable genres from different disciplines. (WR)
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

Name: Technical Writing
Description: Surveys the forms and methods of communication used in business, industry and government, including informal and formal reports, letters, resumes, and proposals.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

Name: Advanced Exposition
Description: Advanced composition course in methods of exposition: definition, classification, comparison and contrast, analysis, illustration and identification. (WR)
Prerequisites: Prereq: Junior standing or higher and two 1000/2000-level English courses.

Name: Writing through Media
Description: Course examines media studies and writing. Explores practices of literacy in context of popular culture, including cinema, television, advertising, popular fiction and journalism, including selections from the Western canon.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

Name: Film Analysis
Description: Introduces thinking and writing about the cinema by means of film theory and history. (WR)
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

Name: The Theory and Practice of Modern Criticism
Description: Intensive introductory study of 20th-century criticism theory.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: The Theorists: Black Diasporic Thought
Description: Studies one or more theorists, contemporary or historical.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Introduction to Film: Criticism and Theory
Description: Introduces the principal theoretical and critical issues raised by the first century of the cinema.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: CINEMA OF ENVIRONMENTAL CRISIS
Description: Surveys global cinema of environmental crisis with a focus on historical and contemporary experimental, fiction, and nonfiction films’ representations of human responses to environmental change. In addition to the three hours of weekly lectures, requires attendance at a weekly film screening (up to three hours).

Name: Psychological Approaches to Literature: What Is Desire?
Description: Use of various psychological concepts to the application of literary study. Refer to department website.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Film Studies: Finding Footage: Cin Paratext
Description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of film genres, notable film directors, and other significant topics on subjects related to film.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: National Cinemas: Weimar Cinema
Description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: National Cinemas: Modern Czech Cinema
Description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: National Cinemas: Italian Cinema
Description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Independent Study
Description: For advanced students who desire to supplement the regular courses by independent reading or research under guidance.

Name: Undergraduate Research in English
Description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English.

Name: Honors Seminar: The Great American Novel
Description: Open to English majors who have maintained an overall junior/senior level GPA of 3.5. Small seminar classes study topics in English and American literature or film.
Prerequisites: Prereq: undergraduate coordinator and/or department permission.

Name: English Internship
Description: Admission requires a written proposal of appropriate work experience from the student and a written acceptance for employment from the employer, including designation of a supervisor. Successful completion requires a written summation of the work experience from the student and a written evaluation of performance by the supervisor.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 12 credits of 3000/4000-level work in English and undergraduate coordinator permission.

Name: Department Seminar: American Women's Poetry
Description: Seminar offered on a space-available basis allowing department majors to develop their individual programs of study while focusing on a common topic.
Prerequisites: Prereq: English major and 9 credits of 3000/4000-level work in English.

Name: Department Seminar: bell hooks
Description: Seminar offered on a space-available basis allowing department majors to develop their individual programs of study while focusing on a common topic.
Prerequisites: Prereq: English major and 9 credits of 3000/4000-level work in English.

Name: Honors Thesis Project
Description: Student selects an English faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in preparation of an honors thesis. An abstract and one copy of the thesis must be delivered to 101 Academic Advising Center by the semester deadline specified by the Honors Office.
Prerequisites: Prereq: completion of one semester of ENG 4936; undergraduate coordinator permission. Open to English honors students.

Name: Studies in the Movies
Description: Studies in the Movies

Name: Proseminar in Graduate Studies in English: Research, Writing, and the Profession: Race/Narrative Form/Vict Novel
Description: The proseminar has a two-fold objective: to introduce students to research methods, scholarly writing, and professionalization and to examine of a specific topic in English, Writing, or Media Studies. Students have the opportunity to work in their areas of research. Assignments include bibliographies, academic genres, presentations, and peer reviews.

Name: Individual Work
Description: Individual Work

Name: Research for Master's Thesis
Description: Research for Master's Thesis

Name: Advanced Research
Description: Research for doctoral students before admission to candidacy. Designed for students with a master's degree in the field of study or for students who have been accepted for a doctoral program. Not appropriate for students who have been admitted to candidacy.

Name: Research for Doctoral Dissertation
Description: Research for Doctoral Dissertation

Name: Survey of English Literature: Medieval to 1750
Description: This course fulfills three hours of the general education requirement in humanities and the writing and math requirement while introducing students to some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period, including selections from the Western canon. The breadth and focus of this survey will be determined by the instructor.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

Name: Survey of English Literature: 1750 to the Present
Description: This course fulfills three hours of the general education requirement in humanities and the writing and math requirement while introducing students to some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period, including selections from the Western canon. The breadth and focus of this survey will be determined by the instructor.
Prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

Name: Twentieth-Century British Poetry
Description: General study of the most prominent British poets of the 20th Century with particular emphasis on Yeats, Lawrence, Graves, Eliot, Sitwell, Dylan Thomas, and Ted Hughes.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Renaissance Literature: 17th Century: John Milton's Paradise Lost
Description: Variable topics in Stuart Literature and Culture, 1603-1700. Focuses on or combine topics such as the progress of literary genres; the works of single or paired authors; the social institutions and material conditions of textual production; thematically organized studies of cultural relations between literary and nonliterary texts; issues of gender, religion, nationhood and race; and writing in the era before, during and after the English Revolution. Refer to department website for offered topics.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.

Name: Major Figures of British Literature and Culture: The Brontes
Description: In-depth focus on one or two major cultural figures, such as Marlowe, Austen, Scott, Eliot, Dickens, Yeats, Smith, Ishiguro, Kureishi, etc.
Prerequisites:
Prereq: Prerequisite to all 3000/4000-level courses are six credits of English at the 1000/2000
level or department permission.

Name: Shakespeare: Shakespeare: Divided Selves
Description: Studies selections from Shakespeare. Topics include tracing Shakespeare's dramatic career, concentrating on one or several genres including histories, comedies, tragedies, and romances; developing the history of Shakespeare reception; approaching Shakespeare through performance, including acting and directing; and approaching Shakespeare through feminist, materialist, or psychoanalytic methods.
Prerequisites: Prereq: 3 credits of ENC or CRW or AML or ENG or ENL.
